reviewText:
This game reviewed badly.
The press hated it, and the community didn't get it.
The story was gaped at and lambasted as being one of the worst in gaming.
It caused the death of its development studio, Grin.

And yet, it's still one of my favourite games.

Originally, I bought this when it came out on PS3, having thoroughly enjoyed Bionic Commando: Re-Armed.
I didn't read any reviews, and trusted in Grin to deliver a cracking bionic experience, and they delivered in spades.

It's all about the arm you see; you CAN play it as a straight-up third-person shooter with occasional swingy bits, but to do so is to miss the point entirely.
You should be swinging, punching and throwing at every opportunity. You should be concentrating on evading the enemy through being a target that's impossible to hit.
You should be damn good if you're to get the most out of this game.

And that's what people didn't get; they were fooled by how it looked and were expecting a more open experience. So they played it as such and moaned when they didn't get much out of it in return.

Bionic Commando is a linear game, and it makes no bones about it. It's not trying to be an open-world roamer; it's giving you a series of tightly packed scenarios to let loose upon as you see fit, encouraging you to experiment as much as possible with the sublime tool it's giving you.

And boy, does it reward good play; it has the best use of an achievement system I've come across, even better than Dead Rising (although it definitely took a few queues from there).
Under all other circumstances, I hate achievement systems; they're poorly implemented checklists of things you're likely to do anyway most of the time.

Yet here, the achievement system rewards you in game as well as with achievement points (less noticeable on the PC where they're simply challenges and the subsequent rewards without the Steam achievements).
Manage to kill 3 grunts with one grenade? Congrats, have an upgrade to the amount of nades you can carry!
Taken out 3 grunts with one grenade launcher shot? Aces, your grenade launcher radius is improved!

And each completed challenge may lead to another, more difficult one, meaning you'll scout out opportunities while playing the levels that'll let you complete those challenges. It's rewarding you for excellent play in the best way possible, and never completely overpowered.

On top of this, you have an incredibly well realised vision of a city hit with a recent disaster of apocalyptic scale and some of the best music in gaming. The first encounter with Polycraft, BC's flying mech suits, is a particular early game highlight, with a dramatic, pulse-quickening tune driving your emotions higher as you swing between buildings kicking robot suits out of the air.
It's exhilirating, and makes you realise that BC is one of the best Super-hero" games out there.

reviewText:
It's hard to believe that it's taken Capcom more than twenty years to publish a sequel for Bionic Commando. This game is the long awaited follow up to NES title of the same name. Once again players jump into the bionic boots of Nathan Spencer to swing around via his bionic arm, play with guns and throw cars at a giant mechanical worm.
The story wrapping up the action goes that following the events of the original Bionic Commando cyborgs were tossed out like garbage, while Nathan was used as a scapegoat and sentenced to death for crimes he didn’t commit. Naturally the cybernetically-enhanced people were outraged by this and formed a terrorist group to fight back, detonating an experimental weapon, wiping out the population and destroying Ascension City. Fortunately for Nathan, the attack was on the day of his execution so he gets out of jail to kill the terrorists.
Missions take place in and around Ascension City and for the sake of level linearity most of it – except for the places Nathan needs to go - is dangerously radiated by said experimental weapon. It’s also a good idea to stay out of the water as Nathan sinks like a rock. This is also the biggest point of frustration in this game as there are several portions where you have to swing across floating mine fields - miss a mine and you’re sunk.
Then you have to sit through a load screens which can last several seconds and make what should be a simple second or third attempt a big source of frustration. The second gripe is that these unavoidable load screens are far too common – every time you come to another check point you’re greeted by another one, breaking the flow of gameplay significantly. Fortunately, Grin has done an excellent job on the swinging controls and even indicates to you the perfect time to jump saving you a lot of unnecessary frustration. Holding down the trigger after you jump will cause you to grapple onto the closest target automatically as well.
The bionic arm can also be used as a weapon to throw an object/enemy. Aside from the arm, Nathan has a decent selection of guns too, including his classic machine gun. On top of that Bionic Commando introduces new toys including rocket and grenade launchers - all of which are made available via pod drops throughout the game.
If you can look past several frustrations, you’re in for some impressive environments ranging from the city park, down town areas to deep caves. Navigating them is the simple task of moving from way point to way point, and dispatching enemies along the way.
Although going from “point A, to point B” sounds repetitive, Nathan isn’t your usual silent tough guy – his character carries the game well. He’ll let out a yell when you take an impressive jump or swing. On top of that, he can take a jump from insane heights without dying - where most protagonists in recent memory would crumple.
Bionic Commando also sports some of the craziest boss battles in recent memory, including one against a giant robot worm in a parking lot. The other enemies range in size from swarms of robot insects, to generic soldiers, and armoured soldiers with a weak spot in their back. Some fights will even see you taking on up to three armoured soldiers with nothing but rocks to throw.
Bionic Commando is a strong action game, but it's nowhere near groundbreaking. The groundwork has definitely been set for this franchise and I'm excited to see where Capcom can take it.

reviewText:
I feel like this is overall one of the most underrated and unappreciated games on Steam. Despite a slow start and some small annoyances like a lacklustre story and some weird technical choices, Bionic Commando is very fully featured and comes with its own achievements, collectible/upgrade memories, area notes, a great variety of enemies, excellent boss fights and most importantly a plain old fashioned fun central gameplay mechanic.

Highlights
There were plenty of highlights in Bionic Commando for me and none of them stood head and shoulders above the rest because most components were fully rounded. Large open maps were very rare in gaming until Croteam came on the scene years later, and the textures, changing environments, well designed levels and artifacts all create a compelling and fairly memorable world.
The weapons are also rounded, and in most modern shooters you'll find yourself sticking with just one or two weapons, whereas in Bionic Commando, while the firing animations are occasionally mildly annoying, everything is well designed and different enemies and situations warrant different weapons. The variety of enemies is also worth mentioning, even if I thought the standard grunts were frivolous and redundant by the end, the different types of enemies with different variations added a depth to combat, and the boss fights all have a small setup, good intro animations and a genuine need to remember arm moves and combat techniques to progress which harks back to the good oldschool learn-and-apply method.

* Consiquential achievements are far too rare and they're used here to give you upgrades and extras when you experiment with your abilities. They actively reward varied play. Bulletstorm is the only other game I can think of off-hand that does anything similar and it's very welcome.

Mistakes and Annoyances
There was nothing game-ruining here, but there were a few annoyances worth mentioning. Right off the bat the tutorial segment is a frustration because the controls are mapped for console rather than PC, which stand out because the mechanics take some time to get used to. Small things like the unskippable cutscenes which made for waiting several seconds to load the same boss fight each time you died, collectibles having a strange audio flag that pulled you out of any immersion, and the God awful menu system which makes you go through 3 menu progressions, then reload back to the title screen, then access another two menu points to quit just boggle the mind. Together these small annoyances made this feel like a slightly weaker title.

The other thing that actively takes away from the game though is the marriage between great voice acting and poor dialogue. The dialogue is really subjective, and personally I found the crude humour and occasional bad one-liner fitting for what is essentially a fun mindless action game, but after hiring such great voice actors it's a shame they haven't spent more time and effort on the story and writing, which could've easily made a good game great.

Recommendations
At just £6.49/9.99€/$9.99 at the time of review, Bionic Commando clocks in at an average play-time of 8 hours and the collectibles add at least another 6 or 7 hours for completionists. This is also a fantastic game to come back to and I can see anyone interested in speedrunning having a blast trying for a faster completion with this game.

My conclusion then, is that this is good value for money and a good buy for anyone who doesn't mind a mildly dated and fairly mindless but strong platforming shooter with a hidden depth of ability.

The whole revival of the Bionic Commando IP happened at an unfortunate time in history. It was when nearly every company was looking to have their games be more darker, serious and brooding.

It happened as Inafune was outsourcing most of Capcom's IPs to Western devs. And to be fair maybe that's the only reason this series ever made a comeback. Because of Grin's interest in the series. Or atleast that's my take from it. Even having tried to work on Strider and Streets of Rage as we know now. But back to this series. Grin made two pretty decent Ghost Recon games (and the racing game Ballistics) before making Bionic Commando Rearmed. I had no idea what the series was at the time but the remake received pretty unanimous praise back then and after playing it later I must say it's an amazing game. It's a frolicking Indiana Jones -esque action platformer where you gun down nazis and eventually explode Hitler's head in graphic, satisfying detail. It's a colorful adventure with funny writing and with gore in appropriate places. It plays, sounds, looks and reads great and it had it's own distinct vibe.

Now how does this relate to the Bionic Commando Reboot and to what I said earlier about bad timing? That vibe is gone. See when Grin could reimagine the series for the reboot, they took all the story elements and made them super super serious. Basically gave it the ol' 'Man of Steel' treatment. Nathan Rad" Spencer is now an angry vet with cornrows and a gravely voice. He's been left to rot in jail for years after saving his country but having been sentenced for "war crimes". Nathan is called to action one last time by his old friend Super Joe who also talks all broody and is voiced by Steve Blum doing his Jack Cayman voice. Joe tells Spencer that unknown terrorist group has nuked one of their cities
date:
killing millions and it's up to Spencer to traverse the city and find out who's behind the attacks. Spencer also looks to find his lost wife.

Also worth mentioning briefly is that Nathan Spencer is voiced by Mike Patton whose music I love but I think he's terribly casted in this game and his delivery doesn't come across believable in the slightest. He's better at voicing characters like the Darkness.

(Spoiler) Super Joe later turns out be evil and it's revealed that Joe killed Spencers wife so that her mind could be put into Spencer's trusty Bionic Arm for it to have worked in the first place. Joe and Spencer later have their final battle in the sky. Joe ends up dieing with Spencer falling down out of the sky. It's uncertain if Spencer actually dies and the game ends with cliffhanger with no sequel in sight ever. (End Spoiler)

It's these kinds of changes to the story and mood that affect other areas of the game and by extension my enjoyment. You see form follows function. So with a darker mood in the story comes a darker color palette and environments in the art direction. That said the game is too grey. reviewText:
People will call this a bad game. It really isn't. (Depends on your computer though.) It's a rather short game, only lasting about 5 hours if you get good at it. But those five hours have a lot going for them.

The combat is excellent, always pushing you to do your best against the multides of enemies. But it reaches a point where it keeps throwing the giant mech robots at you (Which is conviently after you learn how to use and instant kill grapple.) The combat manages to flow smoothly into the swinging mechanic, and you can zip around the area, using that as your advantage against the many enemies the game hurls at you.
There is seriously nothing more fun than tossing your enemies around like little dolls.

But, the game has an challenge mod, where you get in-game abilities and perks for completeing them. The problem? This only works in story mode. If you level jump to an earlier area, you can can't collect any missed collectables or try to complete any challenges. So, if you like to speed through the game and keep the momentum going, you'll miss out on a lot.

The boss fights are hit or miss. Some, like the fight against a giant robot worm, manage to be exciting. Others, like the last boss, are annoying. None of them really take advantage of the swingings, so you'll be fighting bosses on a lot of flat areas. (It would have been really fun to fight the last boss by swinging off his flying drones and shooting him from above.)

The story though, and by extension the big plot twist, is bare bones and stupid. Your goal is to fight off some terrorists while trying to find out what happened to your wife. New characters come in and pop away forever in the same cutscenes they're introduced in, and very little feels resolved. The game even ends on a cliff hanger, and you just feel cheated by the end.

Do I recommend this game? Yes. But get it on sale. Like for 2 dollars. Because it won't last long enough (Since the multiplayer servers are down forever) to justify a big price. (There is a reason it's only 1$ to buy it for a console.)

reviewText:
I've only played 2 spiderman games before (both demos) Spiderman The movie and Spiderman, the one where smoke is at the bottom. Both were kind of boring to me. This wasn't. It was awesome.

Story

You play as Nathan Spencer a guy who is on death row. He is released and given a chance to earn his freedom and the location of his wife by taking down the enemies in a town that was nuked. You fight against Bio Reign a pro bionic terrorist group. In the time between the NES game and this one bionics are outlawed because of a rumor that it causes agression (and other reasons). Yes it sounds like a Hollywood remake of something simple (like half the shows on TV) but it works out fine. The story is very cool and is told through conversations between Super Joe and Spencer and messages on relays. Half of the time Spencer is serious but the other half he is not. When killing enemies he sometimes gives one liners like Sucks to be you!" and "Go long son!". When he tries to put a password in and it isn't right he says "Well that sucks". Also the big gunmen are cocky and call you names that a 7th grader would make.

Gameplay

You use your bionic arm to attach to objects and swing. Use W to swing forward and S to swing back. You can also "reel in" to objects (attach to it and ram yourself towards it). It's very fun and you can go far with it. Lots of people say it's hard but it's not really hard to me. In midair even if you are not close enough to your latch target yet you can hold the cursor there and when your body gets close enough it will latch on. The harder thing to do is to reel in to attack bionics in the back (if you dont aim right you will latch to the ground). There are two kinds of enemies
date: regular gunmen and bionics. Gunmen can be killed by your guns and grenades or your bionic arm. You can throw objects in the world at them

fling an enemy up and throw one at the other. The bionics are the real fun enemies to fight. You swing around looking for objects to throw while dodging their attacks and then wait till they get close enough to attack while worrying that they will get you before you can throw the object. It's very fun and intense.

Music

The music is really good. It is very epic and sounds patriotic for some reason. Most of the tracks are remixes of the original theme (which are still good) but some of them are ambient and it has a very cool action theme. There is a fight in a library that will give your goosebumps because of how epic the music is making it.

You will feel so free when you play this game and swing. You can go great heights in distance and combat with just your arm. And it's pretty easy despite what others say. Checkpoints are available right before big fights so I don't understand why some reviewers like GT said they weren't. I'm speaking as a novice to the series; this title is my first game in the franchise. With that out of the way...

... I think whether you enjoy BC or don't - depends on the difficulty setting you intend to play on. Seriously. You get a choice of: NORMAL, HARD and COMMANDO. You can't change your choice afterwards. I like to get the most out of my games, so I chose COMMANDO immediately. And on COMMANDO... things get very very very very messy, and still other things which would make the game challenging now make it cheap.

And that's what BC is: C-H-E-A-P. And I don't mean price-wise.

BC's challenging (or frustrating) difficulty comes from its checkpoint system, where they're pretty far apart. And basically your character Spencer is not a badass; he's a wimp that can get killed by each and any single enemy you encounter. You're armed with a pea-shooter, and occasionally you're given special secondary weapons with very limited ammo. But the pea-shooter's your main thing. Piu-piu-piu-piu, goes Spencer as he has to fire 5-10 bullets into one soldier. Bam, bam, bam, goes the soldier as he kills you in three. Oh, and they can shoot you from literally miles away, even if you don't see them. Reload checkpoint.

Oh, your extendable grappling arm - aka your bionic part that the game's all about? Yes, you can grab enemies with it, toss them around. But about 0.5 seconds after you hook onto them, they whip out a sort of taser and send a jolt across the arm. If you're not at full health then - you're dead. Reload checkpoint.

You can go melee with the foes. And yes, they will again whip out their taser and bash you with it. Health scenario from above? Reload checkpoint.

Snipers? One hit takes you out, with your default health. There's always at least 3-4 of them aiming at you from different directions. They can shoot you across the whole map. Ka-bam! Reload checkpoint.

There's robots - flying nimble crafts, or heavy earth-bound behemoths that will pump you full of led and rockets. You can't just shoot them, there's a technique to beat each. And yes, they will soon start coming out in pairs and trios. Reload checkpoint.

Scenario: you take out a pair of flying polycrafts in a crazy battle, and while you take a second to congratulate yourself, some 5-6 soldiers parachute from the sky and shoot you dead. Checkpoint? Oh, it was placed BEFORE the fight with the polycrafts. Enjoy! And the game's full of it, so full of this damn cheapness that about a third of the way in I just thought of giving up... and I rarely, rarely, rarely give up on a game, at least for difficulty reasons.

You die in 5 seconds if you fall into water, because Spencer can't swim since his arms weighs a ton. If your stray a little from a seemingly open-world levels, you die of radiation" in an equally quick amount of time.

Despite it all - BC is a GOOD GAME... as much as that's hard to believe. The Spiderman-like mechanics of your bionic arm are pretty neat

reviewText:
This game is all flash and very little bang. The gimmick is cool to start off with but the rose tinting soon fades and you are left with an incredibly annoying and repetitive game that offers very little in the way of fun. You will find yourself falling to your death a lot.
The game itself runs well and I had very few performance issues, but with a game of this age that’s not surprising. The combat is alright, it has its moments but they are few and far between. The enemies are not varied at all, once you have fought a few you have fought them all.

The setting is pretty cool, I love this sort of thing, a huge destroyed city to swing through. But there is no exploration, you are railroaded to where you need to go. The story also is ridiculous. It makes little to any sense and that is when they bother to have any storyline in the first place.

If the idea of swinging around appeals to you then have a go. That being said don’t bother trying to finish it as the payoff is lame, pointless and full of more holes than swiss cheese.

Have fun? ^_^

reviewText: Bionic Commando is a game I loved most of the time and hated at other times. The game obviously centers around using your arm to swing around the world and fight bad guys with various weapons and abilities. The basic structure goes something like this: Swing through a short entry area, swing through the world and shoot/throw/punch enemies and swing to the end of the area, and repeat. This is broken up by a few really fun boss fights, and is mostly fun. I think the best part of this game is the main mechanic: the arm. you left click to launch your hand and grip an object, and you can swing from there. the catch is, you have to manually aim where you want to swing every single time. while it feels awkward at first to control and may turn you off,  but once you get a hang of the swing mechanics and weight of your character it becomes an absolute BLAST to fly through the stages at lighting speed. The arm lets you do other things, like grab and enemy and throw them at others, kick up and punch cars around like paper, and zip from one end of the arm to another. unfortunatley, this concept is limited by some odd design decisions. the levels are very linear, and you're often punished for exploring by being hit with radiation, this game's form of the invisible wall. radiation kills you almost instantly, and i found myself sometimes swinging to get away from an enemy mid-combat only to land somewhere i wasn't supposed to only to be killed. the guns are also somewhat tame in comparison to the arm, and feel especially weak as a result with a few exceptions. Your pistol is your main weapon and gets things done but is mundane. the other weapons are the highlight here, and most shine. the machine gun tears through enemies, the rocket launcher homes in on minibosses, the grenade launcher destroys everything in the game, the shotgun rips anything apart, and the sniper, wel... snipes. the problem with these weapons is their relative rarity, and ammo is SCARCE for these things. you will almost never run out of pistol ammo but for most of these bigger weapons you'll only get 8 shots for (with the rocket launcher and machine gun being exceptions, 4 rockets and 400 bullets respectivley). these are satisfying, but you'll be afraid to use them because of the scarcity of ammo around the game. the story is very B-movie like, and the main character is unlikable throughout the entire game. the music though? top notch remixes of the original NES themes will have your adrenaline going. all in all, Bionic Commando is not for everybody. It is a flawed game for sure but if you are like me and give it a chance you might just have some fun with this one. Keep this one at arm's (heh) length, but don't be fooled by those who panned it harshly because it's still a good amount of fun.

reviewText:
In terms of pure game mechanics, Bionice Commando 2K9 is an absolute hidden gem.

Very few games handle 3-D swinging properly, and it can be quite a difficult mechanic to implement, yet it's done so with aplomb here. On top of that, the game combines this swinging with a militaristicly styled 3rd person shooter to create a very unique experience of highly mobile tactical shooter (thanks to your generally small health bar and generally limited amount of ammunition and weapon carrying capacity).

When this game is firing on all of its cylinders, you'll have truly amazing moments where you'll Spider-Man around large maps taking out squads of enemy soldiers, their air support, and mechs bit by bit fighting against larger numbers and gravity all at once. And it can be glorious.

However, there are a host of very real problems too:

> The radiation walled death zones can be very, very annoying
> There isn't enough enemy variation in either the number of types of opponents, nor the AI for the more advanced ones present in the game
> There DEFINITELY aren't enough bosses, and only one boss battle takes full advantage of all of the player's mechanics
> The weapons are functional, but not terribly imaginative
> The linear progression of levels is not the best choice considering the player's abilities - one big sandbox or multiple smaller sandboxes would have made much more sense considering the nature of your moveset
> The world's tone is trying to ape Gears of War bleakness far too much, but doesn't have either that game's Bromancing or gallows humor to add necessary levity to the experience, and just becomes the king of Edgelord Grim-Dark apathy
> The plot gets mind-bogglingly stupid two-thirds in while leaving off on a horrible note that includes a bunch of QTE's in a game without any of them up to that point (with a terrible cliff-hanger tease on top of it all), and finally . . .
> they seriously spit on the character of Super Joe, who is ostensibly the original Capcom mascot (you'd think they'd have treated him better, considering).

(Oh, and the Multi-player, which is just as amazing as the absolute best the SP has to offer - think UT/Quake 3 style tournament shooting DM with grapple swinging all over the pretty big, very vertical maps - has never found even a small audience, and so is very dead)

But all of that said - this is still a great experience every once in a while to load up and play through a run on a weekend. A fine little adventure that showed off some great mechanics that could have been very well served in a sequel that would have more time to be developed (and which understood the proper level and enemy design for a swinging super-soldier character type).

In a way, it's painful to play as a result. Because you can TASTE the missed potential with this series. But if nothing else, this might be the best possible game to teach game design: it shows you so many Do not do this" lessons
date: while still retaining a core of solid gameplay that you can tell it wasn't incompetence of craftmanship that was the problem here.\n"

A pretty fun decent game. Has pleasant graphics and solid smooth gameplay. The sound is good and the music is not bad. I wish I would have payed more attention to this when it came out in 2009 because I am having a good time playing it. Well mostly. The grappling swinging controls are not as awesome as a lot of user reviews would lead you to believe, but they are competent. The problem being that swing points are usually too close together making consistent swinging very awkward to do. It is also very hard to gauge when to release to swing outward correctly even though it shows you a blue icon letting you know when. You still have to pinpoint release to swing even remotely how you want to, which leads to a lot of swinging straight up or at a upward angle, or too low, as opposed to straight forward or at a much desired but very hard to do forward upward angle to propel you forward correctly. The third person shooting aspect is forgettable especially since the only weapon you have in the game is a pistol, although you can find secondary weapons sometimes like a minigun which blows, or a grenade launcher which rocks. You can also punch objects into the air then jump up and punch them at your enemy, or you can latch your grapple onto an object and whip it into them, or you can grapple onto an enemy and jump kick them twice to kill them. You can use the jump kick move for a lot of your kills.

Some parts are not very fun. Mainly the part I just got passed. It didn't make any sense but up until this point, about 4-5 hours into the game, everything was very easy, then all of a sudden I had to fight two robots and the difficulty spiked massively from a 2 to a 9 and they are not even bosses, just regular enemies. They are not exactly fun to fight until I just swung objects into them with swing grapple and on like my 5+ try I killed them.

Overall it was a solid purchase. I think I payed $2.50 for it and at that price it was a very good deal. Do not pay more than $5 though because it is a pretty short game. 7/10

reviewText:
I really want to like this game, but it's very difficult too. I would recommend it on an extreme sale, but overall (even for $10), I cannot.

A slow start to a game, and certainly a slow start to a story. They did a decent job trying to keep the old Commando perks in the game (from sounds, clothes, and music), but for what they have, they could have upped the intensity of the situation. The story doesn't feel like it impacts the game what so ever.

The game overall is decent. The premise of it feels somewhat correct, and the bionic arm isn't as limiting as some reviewers say. Although be it so, the arm's momentum feels very stiff (maybe that's the way a machine arm is supposed to be) and the swing mechanic feels limiting. One would imagine themselves swinging all over the level, but in reality one can only go in the direction that is blatantly laid out in front of them. The distance the arm can be used is also a factor, as it is not very far. There is the capability of using melee, in which the coolest part is knocking an enemy near a ledge and watching their animation struggle not to fall. Problem is, it's quite bland and doesn't give the player any impression of an impact. The shooting is bland and literally feels like it was put together in seconds. You can zoom in for a better view, and yes there are different weapons (not really to choose from, rather wait for the proper drops throughout the levels), but shooting and fighting enemies feels like a grind. Enemies aim is quite well, and snipers will take you out if you stay motionless for at tops, three seconds. Spencer can use his bionic arm against enemies, but only to jump in the air once (press A), then zip towards the enemy (pressing A again). They could have done so much more with the arm but it seems they chose not to. They could have given it abilities, or a capability to throw an opponent. Nope, none of that is present here.

A game that could have been that much more, just simply lacks. The multiplayer is alright at best, and probably won't keep you busy for too too long. The choppy-ness of the jumps and the difficulty of grabbing opponents with the arm just all feel flawed. It is nice however, that they did decide to include multiplayer. If you are going to make a game with guns and a bionic arm, maybe try to incorporate the two a little better, or at least try to combine the two. The graphics are alright, and the sounds are basic.

Due to the reasons stated above, I simply cannot recommend it. Unless you are a complete die hard fan of Bionic Commando, is the only way I can say buy it... and even then on sale. It hurts me to rate this game instead of calling it acclaimed.

reviewText:
I grew up playing Bionic Commando in the 90s. It was a side scrolling masterpiece: innovative gameplay, epic level design and an actual storyline.The kid in me was trembling with expectation when I started playing this 3D sequel.

Although I was annoyed by the many modern gaming sins: no health bar, mandatory/not always well placed checkpoints (now that just added 5h of replaying through parts of levels thank you), invisible level barriers (radiation and water) and etc...Still, I was literally hooked, in part because I was curious to see what's next: the environments are lush even if the level design is either repetitive or slightly inconsistent (often too hard or too easy). By adding more realistic FPS gunplay Grin took away some of the fun of shooting bullets and chasing them while swinging with your arm, in fact shooting and swinging simultaneously is never really required so you're either playing 'Prince of Persia' jumping and flying around or 'Splinter Cell' shooting guards in buildings over the shoulder. The only two cool gameplay mechanics are the dive bomb (death from above) and the abilities to throw objects (even cars and billboards) but Spencer's a total wimp as a couple strong shots will take him down most of the time and even near the end of the game he has limited abilities and a small arsenal (only 4 classic guns). And as the controls are far from perfect (specially for precision swinging) you will die abundantly.

There are some epic moments like the boss fights, but all in all this feels for fans only, the amount of pleasure to be derived from this mechanical arm is somewhat inferior to the pain. But if you wanna find out why the hell Spencer has dreadlocks this is the game for you!

reviewText:
!SPOILERS AHEAD!

Please note, this review is written in bullet-point form, as that's all it deserves.

What Bionic Commando did right:
Large, open areas idea for free-roaming with the grapple
Good use of grapple/momentum technology
Large, glowing hidden objects, requires skill  as well as finding them
Satisfying use of the grapple system to throw or throw at enemies
Interesting use of challenges to reward upgrades
Nice use of enemy dialogue
Played on Hard first time – difficult, but not impossible

What it did wrong:
Last-gen use of checkpoint system with very few checkpoints
Instant death pitfalls, invisible walls, fire and water
Limited incentive to collect hidden objects
Hidden items requiring very risky jumps that will easily kill you and require you to start again
Clunky aiming system
Some long, vulnerable animations (Kiteing)
Very basic gun system
Limited use for the melee system
Clunky in-game menu
Generic hide-to-heal health system
Enemies see you from far too far away, no stealth element
Badly voiced, unlikeable main character
Tenuous plot, badly written script
Gigantic plot holes: What is the 'item'; What did they plan to do with it; Who is the 'Sniper; What is the purpose of Mag's character (dies); Main character's unclear death at the end; Giant army of angel robots out of nowhere; Absurd betrayal for no clear reason; Main character's wife died so he could have a robotic arm, doesn't seem to bother him; Who are any of these characters (supposedly from previous games)
Terrible quick-time-esque final boss
Unskippable credits

What it should have done:
Melee system like Batman: Arkham Asylum
Use of time-slow while aiming
Heal back only the last full chuck of health on a bar of parts
Decoy weapon/item to lure large groups away/together

CONCLUSION:
This game is clunky, flawed, and written like a bad fan-fiction... but there is some fun to be had here. You may get frustrated, you may find it unfulfilling, but if you get this cheap on sale... why the hell not? And let's make this very clear: I'm recommending this because why not". It's not good

The game is developed and published capcom with some help from grin a company known for such great games as wanted weapons of fate and terminator salvation. So if the games that came before and after bionic commando are to speak for the quality you should think about dropping your expectations but even if you do the game soil itself right of the bat by dropping you in, locked up in chains. You don't know why then some ♥♥♥♥♥♥ bag sets you free just to tell you ay sorry we locked you up for 5 years but we need you to work for us now and we know about your missing wife so ♥♥♥♥ off. Woah I really want to save the world now. After the kick in the balls of an intro the game drops you into the mission with one arm and just a standard pistol and tells you to get your other arm. Thats simple alright only problem is the movement is clunky just walking around, you have a dodge that takes at least 4 seconds to do and gets you nowhere Its more of a harm to do it. so getting to your arm with around 10 enemies on the path is pretty ♥♥♥♥ when you die in 3 hits, get used to that because there are no health ups to my knowledge. Once you beat everyone and get your are the game opens up in a big way in terms of movement.  You get ability to grapple to walls and pull yourself in or swing if you have the moment. THIS  and only THIS is a redeemable factor in this whole game. Crippled by a bad story, bad level design, and bad combat the only thing that got me through this 6 hour long campaign was some of the cool stuff I can do with the swing. Heres where I direct you back to my potato/bacon comparison. if you want to bite through all the bad potato, chew it up, and swallow it. This is one of the most fun action games I have ever played.

It's actually fun to just move around in this game.  How many other games can make that claim?  Swinging around through the levels to get to places is actually fun and enjoyable.  On top of that, the combat is kept engaging with a wide variety of ways you can dispatch your opposition. The only downsides to this game are things that aren't related to the actual game itself.  The story is terrible and so predictable you can set your watch by it.  For being a AAA game, you might expect there to be more variety in the environments, objects, character models, etc.  There's also some obvious in-game advertising, but none of it is anywhere that you wouldn't expect to see a bilboard; it's just that the bilboards are a little unrealistically geared toward a gaming audience.  And personally, I wish the game had levels you could back-track to instead of being arranged in a linear fashion.

But none of these flaws detract from what you really play the game for.  The gameplay is still solid, fun, and amazing.

Summary
Your one death row, but suddenly the government people need you again. They give you back your bionic arm and send you loose to go kill some dudes. In return they will give you information about the location of your girly poo. End of plot and that's ok. The games more interesting aspect in dialogue/plot is just purely how much of a 90's action flick it is.

The Good
The combat feels solid enough without feeling like you are god incarnate killing everybody. The grappling arm feels great as you go swinging around like spider man with a machine gun. The humor is spot on and the game doesn't take itself to seriously.

The Bad
The game feels very linear do to the radiation. Honestly I wanted to explore this game and swing around everywhere and the game just wouldn't let me feel free to do what I wanted. The graphics are somewhat cartoonish and I don't think it was supposed to. The enemies even on normal have absurd accuracy from large distances that you can't hit the broad side of a barn at. The guns and gameplay feels relatively dated even for when it was released.

Conclusion
Honestly it's the radiation that made me hate this game. I liked how everything was going at first and then bam dead... Guess I can't go that way lets try going over here... Bam dead. That coupled with enemies hitting me perfectly from distances I could hit them at just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ me off. If you can get passed those two major problems I'd say have at it. The ideas were great and the implementation was mostly ok, but at the end of the day those two things just wrecked it for me.

Value
If you want to give it a try I'd do so at a max of $2.50

reviewText:
I bought and played this game the day it was released for Xbox 360, and thoroughly enjoyed it.  Recently bought it on sale, and decided I would try it again, years later, to see if my opinion still holds. It does. (In depth below, skip to the end for final opinion).

At it's core, the game is an excellent 3D translation of the classic Bionic Commando and remake Rearmed gameplay.  The swing mechanics, while it can take some getting used to, feel precise, even when you screw up using them (getting wrapped around a light pole you have attached the arm trying to swing at an odd angle).  The arm mechanics are adapted well to combat, giving the player many options beyond a gun to kill enemies. Many of these arm combat mechanics were adapted to Rearmed 2, released a year or 2 later. Throwing things with the arm, for me on the PC, did leave something to desire, as it seemed perfectly open throws would fly backwards instead of forward. The weapons part of the combat is pretty typical for a third-person shooter, with the addition of being able to shoot while swinging.

Beyond that, however, is where the game becomes a matter of taste.

The level design is similar to previous installments; mostly-linear levels confining the player to the beaten path (not unlike other modern 3D shooters).  Unlike many 3D linear games, the area boundaries aren't solid.  They consist of radiation which the player only has a few seconds to leave before it kills them, or water in which the player has a few seconds to use the bionic arm to escape before drowning (lenient considering most games, and previous installments, killed the player instantly for entering water).  I thought the level design is fine, conveying the developers' intent to have the player roam through the city completing missions for the government.

Game progression is slow relative to the length of the game itself, and the pacing of the game is terrible.  By the time the player unlocks all arm abilities earned through game progression, the game is over halfway finished.  And the game itself is too short, probably a good 2-4 hour experience from start to finish depending.  The game needed at least another major section.

The story, while quirky and excessively profane, left a lot of things to be desired. And the soundtrack, while I quite enjoy it, doesn't have much variety.  I would say about half of the soundtrack is either a loose remix, or uses several parts, of the first level theme from the original Bionic Commando/Rearmed.

In the end though, the game is worth the current price ($10), and definitely any sale price.  Ignoring the story, the slow start to the gameplay picks up greatly about a third of the way through the game and you'll be flying around full speed about halfway through.  Combat is simple, and the arm and swinging opens up a variety of ways to destroy the enemy, which doesn't get old.

Pick it up, don't take it too seriously, and it should be a good time.

reviewText:
Bionic Commando is a seriously underrated game. It is a sequel to Bionic Commando Rearmed and the story continues off from there, placing the player in charge of Nathan Spencer.

Story: The game has a cliched story about a soldier seeking revenge after some people do him wrong. The characters aren't all that interesting and the voice acting in general is pretty mediocre, especially in Nathan Spencer's case. My god does he have an annoying and unlikable voice.

Graphics: The graphics for Bionic Commando are passable, just good enough to justify being in the PS3/Xbox 360 era. The game is in HD and the character models and environments are crisp, but don't expecting breathtaking graphics like Uncharted 2.

Gameplay: This is where Bionic Commando shines. It is a lot of fun to zip around obstacles and the environments using Spencer's bionic arm. It is also very tricky at times to get around, as the control system can be a bit finicky and you might lose track of where you are (using the bionic arm can be very tricking when swinging and grappling onto balloons).

Overall, Bionic Commando is an enjoyable game that may not win any awards but is worth your time and money. It is definitely too harshly criticized and is by no means a bad game.

I'd give it a 7/10.

reviewText:
This game has some prettyminor issues; but they became glaring problems when you need them to work perfectly to survive in Hardmode. I was already inundated with knowledge of how to play the game when I played the demo way back when this was first set to launch. I had a lot of fun; but I ultimately was not financially set enough to just buy the games I wanted at the time. Fast-forward to 2016, and I find myself buying the Humble Bundle containing this game as a bonus. Naturally I picked to play the game on Hardmode, since I already know how to play the game pretty well. I was hoping the game would give a decent challenge, and I feel much of that expectation has been met.

To refresh myself with the games controls, I took care to pay close attention to the Tutorial. Swinging, Throwing, Ripping, Heavy Uppercut Launching, and Shooting were the main subjects covered in it. To my dismay, I would find out during the actual game that I wouldn't be able to use these skills until I reached a point in the game where it would be important to progression. This of course made enemies more difficult than they should of been when I didn't have the tools I had learned to use in the Tutorial. It's one of the few negative about this game; but it's not really gamebreaking. Not being able to throw items at the first biomechs was just annoying, I was forced to use Handgrenades or rely on luck in hitting their back hatch with the pistol(as there was not enough ammo in the bonus weapon they drop for you to use).

This game makes good use of Bonuses, Challenges, and Hidden Retro Icons. You're never really left that often with an empty area; although the Retro Icons are never hidden that well. They're more or less sprawled out to challenge your swinging ability. This isn't really handled well since dying means you have to get everything you got before the next Checkpoint. I don't really have an issue with this; but It was annoying to have to rewatch certain cutscenes or grab collectibles all over again. I found myself skipping things I had already done upon dying, to save myself the sanity of fighting that extra mobs of enemies again.

After fumbling a bit with the controls, I managed to learn of a very unique way in taking down the Biomechs. There is some deep meta with this game in regards to enemy ventilating; but sadly there isn't much variety in enemies to explore. The trimming of this unrefined depth to gameplay; was most likely for thesake of the tacked on multiplayer. This game came out right around the time Multiplayer games were being churned out left and right, so single player experiences were routinely hampered by the need to substantiate XBL subscription costs. Too bad they couldn't just work on the Single Player more, a great deal of time had obviously gone into making the swinging feel so good; but the limitations in regards to invisible walls(Death Radiators), Sparse selection in weapons, and overall underwhelming-swiftness to the plot, brings down the rest of the lasting appeal.

To tie it all together, it's not a bad game; but its way too quickly snapped together with lots of underwhelming bits, creating a very desultory feel to the game. Swinging, Fighting Enemies, and stealthly navigating the scenary, make the experience all the more fun. Perhaps multiplayer could be fun as well; but I'm not really interested in multiplayer games. Had this game poured it's heart into the Single player, it would be much better than it is. In the current day, this is probably the last we'll ever see of another Bionic Commando game; but I really hope there comes a time where the idea is explored again.

reviewText:
I'd be lying if I said I don't enjoy this game, but I'd also be lying if I said I love this game.

Bionic Commando is a sequel to the original NES game (or Rearmed which was made to bring the younger generation up to speed and you totally play that one) that starts Nathan Spencer being called to do a mission after being imprison for years and Bionics are shunned. The story is pretty samey to a lot of other story: There's a macguffin you need to get, your characters a bitter hardass while mission control snarks at you and you need to complete your mission against an army of Not-Nazis and save the world. Of course that's not EXACTLY the story but that's what I felt as a good summary. Spencer comes off as an ♥♥♥ compared to his radical self in the original and Rearmed (with good reason but still) and Super Joe shows up but he's an ♥♥♥ as well. The entire universe of Bionic Commando got a lot grittier in this one, and while it's not a huge deal for me, when I keep hearing swearing during gameplay I get the feeling it's trying too hard to be mature rather than just letting it come out on its own.

The gameplay it rather abstract but nice. Swinging around feels pretty good (though it says ♥♥♥♥ you physics) and you can grab onto almost anything you can think of on the environment and using your arm to pull off throws and impressive feats makes you feel like a badass while Spencer hoops and hollers like a madman. Gunplay is pretty meh, you have your pistol which you will be using most of the time, it's somewhat reliable but it god it eats through ammo, you also get a special weapon that can be swapped out and grenades, but good luck keeping a special weapon you like, because special weapon pick-ups are rare as hell. Also using the throwing technique is a bit add because after kiting, throwing leads to items being flung in a very odd and nonsensical angle before being throw which leads to odd situations (like a mook flying off to the right before stopping for a split second and zipping the other way to hit the thing you wanted to hit). Combat in general is kinda nice but I've come to realize 3 things about it

1.Your Bionic arm is your best friend. Seriously by late game I only used my weapons to take care of Biomechs quickly or when I had to shoot someone on the double. Throwing OP
2. Spencer cannot take a hit worth a damn in this game, but nothing's stopping from swinging to safety and healing up like a ♥♥♥♥♥, which kind of takes away from the momentum of gameplay if you ask me.
3. Biomechs can go to hell, because they're annoying as hell and they WILL swarm you by lategame. Also aiming at their weakspot can easily lead to Spencer shooting his arm at a barrel right beside them as much as their back which leads to much frustration

Also another major issue I have with the game is that it railroads you hard. What I mean by that is that you'd expect to be able to swing around and enjoy yourself and your mobility taking out bad guys however you see fit. However, you can't as radiation has covered the city and the very second you hit an area with radioactivity, you only have a few seconds before you're dead. This gets ridiculous as you're swinging around avoiding gunfire or looking for collectibles (which do very little from what I've seen) and then all of a sudden you hear a blaring warning signal before Spencer flops over dead taking you back to a checkpoint. Speaking of which when you die, you go back and all your progress (objectives, ammo, and collectibles) are gone and you have to get them all bad.

The ending is screwy and while I won't spoil it, I feel like it was just a waste of potential of what could have been an amazing final boss.

Overall, give it a shot if you find this on sale, but it is a hit and miss game. It's not horrid but you can easily hate it as much as you like it. Just be warned that this PC port is lackluster compared to other ports and is rather lazy, it's crashed twice over the course of the game for me, has no windowed options or even any graphics settings so if you have a low-end computer you probably won't be able to play this.
